text: thanks for stopping by today's video is
a follow-up video from last week's
homologous and analogous structures and
this week we're talking about vestige el
structures now vegetal structures are
left over from evolution their structure
that used to have a function in an
ancestor species but is useless now in
the modern species so the first example
we're going to look at is in humans and
that's the erector pili muscle and the
erector pili muscle is responsible for
giving you goosebumps when you get the
chills or when you're you know you have
an adrenal response because you're
you're feeling anxious are scared about
something in you and you get goose bumps
and animals now they still do this but
their fur puffs out you look at bears
and and monkeys and things like that and
they do it either when they're cold to
stay warm or when they feel a threat to
make themselves look bigger but for us
it doesn't work that way right we don't
have enough hair to make it have an
effect so it's really useless for us but
anciently if you look back at our
ancestors they used it for the same
purpose that many animals do today the
next thing we look at is the caucus or
the tailbone again in humans it's not
functional there's no purpose if you
went without it you'd be totally fine
but it's they're all the same and again
it shows a structure left over from our
ancestors which had tails and then the
last one's going to talk about the
baleen well the baleen well has this
remaining hip joint here which is
reminiscent of its ancestors which had
four limbs of course the well has no
four limb or anything there but it still
has those bones from the from the hip
joint okay so that's all hopefully that
helped let me know if you have any
questions and let me know what you guys
need what what what are you guys
studying that you're having difficulty
with if you let me know enough in
advance I can make a video on it and I
can help you understand it better so
comment below with things like that
subscribe for more and remember sharing
is caring Thanks
